awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF: What is the role of metasomatic alteration in subduction zone episodic tremor and slip?
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

Dr. William Hoover has been awarded an NSF EAR postdoctoral fellowship to carry out research and educational plans at the University of Washington alongside mentor Dr. Cailey Condit. Dr. Hoover will investigate the role of water-rock reaction in producing the enigmatic seismic phenomena known as episodic tremor and slip (ETS) that can precede large, damaging earthquakes, particularly along subduction zone faults. This study will focus on rocks from Catalina Island (Southern California) exhumed from depths characteristic of ETS in modern subduction zones (e.g., Cascadia in Washington and Oregon). Integrated macro- and micro-scale structural and geochemical analysis will reveal how rock alteration by fluid flow yields deformation behavior characteristic of ETS. This work will provide important direct observations of rocks from ETS source regions and inform modern subduction zone monitoring and seismic research. During field work on Catalina Island, Dr. Hoover will teach a field course to students from Hispanic-serving institution Cal State Channel Islands and mentor capstone research projects. He will also develop and present educational activities as part of the University of Washington Rockin’ Out K-12 outreach program. Lastly, this research will be carried out on land of the Gabrielino-Tongva Tribe and he will return tangible benefits of the research through outreach events held for the tribe. 

Rheological modeling of ETS suggests that it may be hosted within metasomatic talc and chlorite schists, and Dr. Hoover will test this hypothesis using the exhumed rock record. He will identify geologic equivalents of the structures and fluid-rich conditions inferred from geophysical studies of ETS source regions through field mapping of the Catalina Schist (CA). He will connect outcrop-scale deformation partitioning to metasomatic changes with bulk major and trace element and Sr and Li isotope geochemistry. Using spatially-resolved micro-scale chemical and structural analysis with electron microbeam techniques, he will determine deformation mechanisms and connect them to compositional changes across all scales. These observations will be placed in the temporal context of the seismic cycle through bulk Li and intra-crystalline diffusion chronometry. Using this multi-scale approach Dr. Hoover will document how metasomatism controls deformation partitioning and mechanisms at the conditions of ETS in modern subduction zones. These results will inform future geophysical, theoretical and experimental studies of subduction zone seismicity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Subduction zones, where one tectonic plate dives underneath another, host the largest earthquakes on Earth and can threaten life and property in places like Alaska and the Pacific Northwest. Subduction zones also experience slower deformation that can release the energy of an earthquake over days to months, known as slow slip, and can prime a subduction zone for a large earthquake. However, the physical process that produces what we detect as slow slip remains enigmatic. Both large earthquakes and slow slip occur at the boundary between the downgoing and overriding plates, known as the subduction interface, where mantle and crustal rocks are mixed and chemically react due to their dramatically different chemical compositions. These reactions can change the strength of this zone, however, these chemical reactions have received little attention as a catalyst of slow slip. Recently, one model of slow slip based on deformation experiments suggested that chemically reacted rocks rich in the weak mineral talc (used in baby powder) should host slow slip. I tested this hypothesis in natural rocks from Pimu’nga/Santa Catalina Island (California). Field mapping was used to identify a paleo-subduction interface composed of strong blocks of unaltered mantle and crustal rocks wrapped by a deformed matrix of chemically-reacted rocks rich in talc. Minerals found in the chemically-altered rocks place their reaction and deformation at the depths and temperatures where slow slip is observed in modern subduction zones about 97 million years ago. Measurements of the chemistry of these chemically-reacted rocks indicate they formed through a combination of: a) physical mixing of different rock types, b) local exchange of elements between chemically contrasting rocks, and c) addition/removal of elements by water passing through the interface. In talc-rich rocks, crystals of stronger minerals are deformed, fractured, and disaggregated despite being embedded in weak and easily deformed talc. This unusual pattern is best explained by rapid deformation of talc resulting in collisions between strong crystals. This contrasts with deformation textures in adjacent talc-free rocks that suggest typical background deformation rates. Together, these observations are consistent with slow slip events occurring in talc-rich rocks, with intervening deformation occurring in other chemically-reacted rocks, confirming the predictions made by models of slow slip. Evidence of repeated deformation suggest slow slip occurred repeatedly in the talc-rich rocks, similar to repeating slow slip in places like the Pacific Northwest. Talc-rich rocks likely form in modern subduction zones wherever mantle from the overriding plate is in contact with the downgoing plate and could host all deep slow slip in modern subduction zones. This work demonstrates the fundamental importance of chemical reactions to deformation in subduction zones. Chemically-reacted rocks, especially those rich in talc, must be considered in observations and models of earthquakes and slow slip in modern subduction zones to obtain robust and realistic results.

Many science disciplines are grappling with the past and ongoing practice of helicopter research, where scientists remove important data and material from an area without consultation or return of tangible benefit to the local community. Rocks studied with this award were collected on the ancestral lands of the Tongva and in an area with abundant culturally and archaeologically significant sites. Collaboration with a Tongva archaeologist resulted in a sampling protocol where photos and coordinates were provided to the archaeologist for near-synchronous comparison to a database of significant sites. This ensured sampling did not damage these significant sites. This protocol can serve as a model for geoscientists to ensure that their work does not harm local communities.

Undergraduate research projects can be a valuable opportunity to gain experience in data collection and interpretation, build confidence in working independently, and develop science communication skills. I mentored three undergraduate students in developing hypotheses, collecting data, interpreting results, and communicating their findings. This resulted in five student presentations at regional and national scientific meetings. I also helped these students network and frame their research experiences to successfully find jobs in their desired field of earth science.

Earth science is underrepresented in K-12 science curriculums nationwide, but is increasingly important for students who will grow up with a changing climate. I developed and led two educational outreach events at local schools in the Seattle area. These events covered rock and mineral identification, the rock cycle, earthquakes, and Indigenous knowledge of natural hazards and engaged students in hands-on activities. These events served over 40 students in grades K-4.
